sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for derived form IV (yes / no and example!).

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

item.label: yes but only vestigial forms (this does not include MSA loanwords)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Attested with pattern ʔafʕal.
Attested with pattern ʔafʕal.

"Measure IV is attested for Haifa with ʔaḍrab, yiḍrib "streiken", Jewish yuḍrub." However "the number of forms IV elicited is very limited and borrowed from MSA" (Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019: 325)
Attested with pattern ʔifʕal.
Attested with pattern ʔafʕal.
Attested with pattern ʔafʕal.
Attested with pattern ʔafʕal.
Attested with patterns ʔafʕal and ʔifʕal.
Attested with pattern ʔafʕal.
Schukro (2004: 133) notes that Form IV has disappeared and is only present in loans from MSA, having been functionally replaced by form II and I.

cit.quote: he moved away, he kept away

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV has a factitive value. "La valeur générale de la forme IV, comme en arabe standard, est factitive" (Younes 2013: 49)

Form IV seems to be in the process of being replaced by form II due to the pressure of sedentary dialects: "Toutefois, sous la pression des parlers sédentaires, la fonction factitive est aussi largement assurée par le schème C1aC2C2aC3: waggaf-ywaggif «faire cesser», sammaʿ-ysammiʿ «faire entendre». On voit en synchronie qu’il existe une concurrence entre les formes IV et II dans des verbes tels que ʾabʿad ~ baʿʿad «éloigner», ʾaṭʿam ~ tạ ʿʿam «nourrir» mais également entre les formes IV et I dans ʾasga ~ siga «abreuver, irriguer»" (Younes 2013: 49).

cit.quote: we get shelter for the night

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Palva 1976: 34: Form IV, even if still living, can only be attributed a marginal status in the morphological system of ʕAǧārma.

The pattern ʔəqtal (ʔəqtal only if C1 is a glottal or a pharyngal) has in all probability long ago lost its prodductivity as a grammatical category having a clear-cut morphological and semnatic contrast to Form I. (Palva 1976:34)
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author (Talay 1999:125) states that the IV stem is now only preserved in a few remnants, mostly derived from Classical Arabic or Bedouin Arabic. Example: aslam - yəslam "to become a Muslim"
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author (Fink 2017:88) notes that form IV is not attested. Verbs of the IV form in Standard Arabic lost the affix ʔa and are expressed with stem I (rād - īrīd instead of ʔarāda - yurīdu)
Löhr (1905:45) notes that stem IV is not used very frequently.
Blanc (1964:111) states that it can only be found in passive participles and sometimes in perfect forms like enṭēt (I gave).
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
Belinkov (2014:44) notes that it is only common for the verb "to give" (yiʕṭi/yinṭi).
The author notes "nur in Bildungswortschatz (aznab, aslam, aṣbaḥ u.e.a.)"
The fourth form in Maltese is almost non-existent. It is only found in the verb 'wera' he showed.

cit.quote: he took something/ he expelled someone from something

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form I and II are used instead of Form IV, e.g. karam instead of ʔakram "he honoured, welcomed."
This form exists but "either borrowings from MSA or emulation of the speech of other Arabs. Instead of Class IV verbs, Gulf Arabs use either Class I or Class II verbs. Examples ʕaṭa, ʕallam"

cit.quote: to wake up, get up in the morning

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV in this dialect has mostly dissapeared and was replaced by Form I and II.

cit.quote: to wake up, get up in the morning

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV in this dialect has mostly dissapeared and was replaced by Form I and II.

cit.quote: to wake up, get up in the morning

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Form IV in this dialect has mostly dissapeared and was replaced by Form II.
Deduced from examples
Note: "After a word ending in /a/ or /ā/ the initial hanza and vowel of the fourth derived form is elided, e.g. mā-xlaf"
Pereira (2010) does not give any information about the form IV.
Yoda (2005) makes no mention of Form IV
Form IV is very rare and most forms are recent borrowings from MSA.
Only in poetry.
Although type-4-forms were recorded "there is no real evidence that the fourth measure is productive since perfect forms of the aC1C2aC3-type were not recorded", neither participles.
Occurs in imperfect only
Only 4 forms were recorded, ársal, ásbaḥ (spend night), áršad (come of age), ámsa (become night), any only in the perfect. In the imperfect they fall into form-1 shapes.
Occurs only in two verbs: anta, banti ('to give') and asba, basbi ('become (morning)').
Extremely rare, only two verbs of that type are listed: anta, banti ('to give') and asbah ('to find yourself in the morning').

cit.quote: he sent, he sends/he will send

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Extremely rare.
IV with the prefix sa-
only for the word ʔaṭā 'to give' > aḥta, anṭa or anta
became like the I, ʔṣbaḥa > ṣbaḥ 'getting up in the morning'
